description: God Hand is the featured game of the 45th installment of Super Replay. Beginning with Episode 7 a second game; Asura's Wrath, was added to the Super Replay. This marks the first time since Resident Evil a Super Replay featured two games. Andrew Reiner is the host, with Joe Juba on the sticks. Joining them are Ben Reeves and Leo Vader.
The first episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "A Poison Chihuaha!?"

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – God Hand Ep 1: A Poison Chihuaha!?
youtubeVideo.description: We're finally doing it! Today Reiner, Joe, Reeves and Leo begin their journey into the wacky world of God Hand.

description: The second episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "A Free Trip To China".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – God Hand Ep 2: A Free Trip To China
youtubeVideo.description: The game begins to show its true potential for difficulty as Reiner, Joe, Reeves and Leo descend further into the bizarre world of God Hand.

description: The third episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Yankee Doodle Dandy".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – God Hand Ep 3: Yankee Doodle Dandy
youtubeVideo.description: Reiner, Reeves and Leo kick back and watch Joe overcome seemingly insurmountable gameplay challenges as we slowly but surely make our way through God Hand.

description: The fourth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "I Hate It Here".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – God Hand Ep 4: I Hate It Here
youtubeVideo.description: The God Hand is all aces this week as we learn what a joke is, debate what the opposite of a joke is, and posit that perhaps we throw around the word "barbecue" too much.

description: The fifth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Spicy Flavor".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – God Hand Ep 5: Spicy Flavor
youtubeVideo.description: The nightmare continues as we rank every dog in the history of the world.

description: The sixth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Frater".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay - God Hand Ep 6: Frater
youtubeVideo.description: It's the best episode yet as the best gameplay and best conversations happen in perfect unison.

description: The seventh episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Asura's Wrath Ep 1". As joked about seriously talked about in the previous episode this replay switches from a God Hand playthrough to an Asura's Wrath one.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – God Hand Ep 7: Asura's Wrath Ep 1

youtubeVideo.description: Reeves is back to help Asura complete his quest to bring Reiner, Joe and Leo back to their God Hand playthrough.

description: The tenth episode of the God Hand Super Replay is titled "Asura's Wrath Episode 4". This episode continues the playthrough of Asura's Wrath.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – God Hand Ep 10: Asura's Wrath Ep 4

description: Mega Man is the featured game in the 44th installment of Super Replay. Andrew Reiner is the host, and on the sticks is special guest Tim Turi. Joining them are Jeff Cork and Leo Vader.
The first and only episode of the Mega Man Super Replay, with special guest Tim Turi from Capcom.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Mega Man
youtubeVideo.description: Special guest Tim Turi joins Reiner, Cork and Leo for a rewind-abusing playthrough of the original Mega Man, played on Switch in the Mega Man Legacy Collection II.

description: Killer7 is the featured game in the 43rd installment of Super Replay. Andrew Reiner is the host, and on the sticks is Suriel Vazquez, who ranks Killer7 as his favorite game of all time. Joining them are Joe Juba and Leo Vader. Ben Hanson fills in for Leo in Episode 4. Jeff Cork fills in for Reiner in Episode 8. Special guest Goichi Suda joins the crew on a bonus episode.
The first episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "What's On That Shirt?"

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 1: What's On That Shirt?
youtubeVideo.description: Today we begin our descent into madness. Joe, Reiner and Leo join Suriel for a look at his favorite game of all time, the bizarre and unsettling Killer7. Will the gang be able to stay sane throughout the adventure? Or will they be spouting complete nonsense to each other within the first ten minutes of the first episode?

description: The second episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "A Personal Joe Juba".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 2: A Personal Joe Juba
youtubeVideo.description: Our GI Think Tank reconvenes to ponder new, important questions: What's a better name for zombies? Where you would you put Joe Juba's face on your body? Which famous person would you let eat you? Learn all these answers and more as we dive deeper into the twisted world of Killer7.

description: The third episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "Top Five Dissections".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 3: Top Five Dissections
youtubeVideo.description: Reiner, Joe, Suriel and Leo are back to discuss a bevy of hypotheticals while Killer7 happens nearby.

description: The fourth episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "Dat Backside Smile".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 4: Dat Backside Smile
youtubeVideo.description: On this episode of Game Informer's complete playthrough of Suda51's Killer7, Suriel Vazquez, Joe Juba, Andrew Reiner, and Ben Hanson learn way too much about the Loch Ness Monster, Coyote Ugly, oh... and Killer7's gameplay. Enjoy!

description: The fifth episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "The Potato Episode".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 5: The Potato Episode
youtubeVideo.description: Suriel, Reiner, Joe and Leo make their way to Texas in pursuit of a sexual weirdo in our lewdest episode yet. We put our heads together and iron out the Top Ten Dans, and stay tuned after that as we count down the Ten Worst Dans.

description: The sixth episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "Meatloaf Drive-Thru".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 6: Meatloaf Drive-Thru
youtubeVideo.description: The gang is back for more Killer7-adjacent conversation, this time regarding the differences between Suda and Swery, songs that slap, and a great restaurant idea that some people just aren't ready to hear.

description: The seventh episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "Good Jokes".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 7: Good Jokes
youtubeVideo.description: Good jokes ahoy as we get into natural bodily functions, bee attacks, and strategize our group standup special.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 8: The World's Greatest Anagram
youtubeVideo.description: Jeff Cork hosts this episode, just like he always does. I don't even know why I'm calling it out specifically. Suriel, Leo and PJ Jabhouse are along for the ride as we make countless mistakes, tell bedtime stories, and talk about LOAFZ new "Prison Food" ad campaign.

description: The ninth episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "Joe Rogan's Mutant Abilities".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 9: Joe Rogan's Mutant Abilities
youtubeVideo.description: In another installment of our shared psychosis, the gang comes up with new names for the X-Men, denies yarn, and learns how to go. We also make a very exciting announcement regarding Suda51.

description: The tenth episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "Right In The Reiner".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 10: Right In The Reiner
youtubeVideo.description: The Super Replay Podcast continues as we discuss most powerful cereal mascots, the top one Juba, and these Handsome Men we're battling.

description: The eleventh episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "Mister Perfect".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 11: Mister Perfect
youtubeVideo.description: On the penultimate episode, we get real about the strategies and ramifications of using time travel for personal gain. And do a passable impression of James Spader.

description: The twelfth episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "Hours To Live".

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 12: Hours To Live
youtubeVideo.description: On the penultimate episode, we ponder what we would do with limited time left on earth, the impending arrival of Suda 51, and the legend of The Dooking Man.

description: The thirteenth and final regular episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "Finale". A bonus episode replaying the first part of the game with writer and director, Suda51, was announced at the start of the episode.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 13: Finale
youtubeVideo.description:
The story of Killer7 comes to a thrilling conclusion as we define madsturbating, ask why someone would eat a 3 Musketeers bar, and take on Greg Nightmare.

Tune in at the same time next week for one more bonus episode with special guest Suda 51!

description: This bonus episode of the Killer7 Super Replay features writer and director, SUDA51 (aka Goichi Suda).

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Bonus Episode With Suda51
youtubeVideo.description:
We're as surprised as you are, but it really happened. Head of Grasshopper Manufacture Inc. Goichi Suda, also known as Suda51 is here to help us close out our Super Replay of Killer7. Join us for rare insights into the development of Killer7, and see how he answers some of the tough questions and hypotheticals we posed to each other throughout our playthrough.

Much of the time spent translating has been cut for a more succinct video.

description: Vampire Hunter D is the featured game of the 42nd installment of Super Replay. It is the eighth 12/31 Super Replay.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 1
youtubeVideo.description: Happy 12/31 everyone! The year-long wait until the next 12/31 Super Replay is over, and now we can finally start playing our next exciting title from yesteryear. This time it's Vampire Hunter D, the game based on an anime that Kyle likes. Tune in next week for another terrifying episode!

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 2
youtubeVideo.description: After a deadly mistake is made, Reeves assumes the leadership role and does his best to navigate Reiner, Kyle and Leo through the twisted catacombs of the castle.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 3
youtubeVideo.description: The gang's horrifying adventures continue as they endure their most difficult challenges yet en route to recover the elusive "wrench."

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 4
youtubeVideo.description: The changes in leadership continue as we enter our darkest episode yet, with a special appearance from Leo's friend Donnie.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 5
youtubeVideo.description:
On a very special episode of the Vampire Hunter D Super Replay, tragedy strikes the Vampire Hunter D family and they work together to try and pick up the pieces.
And in an even greater tragedy, we lost the game audio. Cutscene audio has been restored but the rest of the episode just has music from the game. Our apologies.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 6
youtubeVideo.description: The gang is working together like a well-oiled machine as Reeves, Kyle and Leo talk about Taco Bell and cartoons while Reiner actually focuses on the game and makes progress. A good Super Replay is all about teamwork.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 7
youtubeVideo.description: Reiner faces some of his most difficult physical challenges yet, while the gang focuses on the intellectual challenges, such as: why are manholes called that? Who was the best character on LOST? What happened to Donnie the Morguetician? All these answers and more in this week's exciting episode.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 8
youtubeVideo.description: Our story races towards a climactic finish as the gang collects plates, fights bosses, and finally gets some answers about Donnie the Morguetician's fatal car accident.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Finale
youtubeVideo.description: The journey of everyone's favorite Dunpeal finally comes to a close in the final episode of our Vampire Hunter D Super Replay. Reiner faces off against the toughest bosses the game has to offer and we say our goodbyes to the friends we made throughout our nine hour tour of the castle.

description: Ape Escape is the featured game of the 41st installment of Super Replay. It is the first live Super Replay, airing on December 1, 2017 starting at 8 am central time. Long asked for by the Facebook Group, it was the reward for reaching the Extra Life 2017 goal.

The Super Replay for Ape Escape began and ended on December 1, 2017 and ran for one live episode. Super Replays of God Hand and Killer7 were announced at the end of this episode, the result of a tied poll on the OverBlood Facebook Group.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay - Ape Escape
youtubeVideo.description: Join the Game Informer crew for the first ever LIVE Super Replay! We're playing all the way through Ape Escape in one sitting. God help us all.

description: Star Fox 2 is the featured game of the 40th installment of Super Replay. The game was developed for the Super NES, but was released for the first time in 2017 with the Super NES Classic Edition. This Super Replay was technically released the day before the game itself released!
Comprised of only one 40-minute episode, this is the shortest "official" Super Replay to date.
The Super Replay for Star Fox 2 begins and ends with Andrew Reiner as host and features Jeff Cork and Ben Reeves.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay - Star Fox 2
youtubeVideo.description:
Join Ben Reeves, Jeff Cork, and Leo Vader to witness Andrew Reiner's potentially record-setting speed run of Star Fox 2, until it inevitably gets smashed when the SNES Classic releases worldwide on September 29th. And come on back tomorrow night at 8 PM Central for your regularly scheduled episode of Replay!

For more on Starfox 2, check out the inside story on the rocky road to release on our website: http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2017/09/27/the-inside-story-on-the-star-fox-sequel-that-took-more-than-20-years-to-release.aspx

description: Pokémon Snap is the featured game of the thirty-ninth installment of Super Replay. Previously a Replay, it was used in the final round in the Super Replay Showdown.

The game features 63 of the original generation of 151 Pokémon. It features 6 main sections (Beach, Tunnel, Volcano, River, Cave and Valley) and a bonus level (Rainbow Isle). The controller is passed between hosts Andrew Reiner and Kyle Hilliard per stage as they compete for the highest photo score.

The nightmarish Sonic the Hedgehog preceded this Super Replay. The emotional strain of it apparently necessitated an extended break from new games in the Super Replay series. This led to the latest start for a new Super Replay in a calendar year, with the first episode airing on July 31.
The Super Replay for Pokémon Snap begins with Andrew Reiner and Kyle Hilliard. Each swapping after a run.

pok.c3.a9mon_captured_this_episode: For overall scores visit the main page.

The main focus of this episode were signs. Reiner captures Mewtwo in the first Cave run. Despite two hit and runs Kyle was able to capture Kingler in his Beach run. Little focus was put on photos leading to low overall scores throughout the episode. The next run to capture the Tunnel Pinsir sign saw Reiner get it on the vehicular bloodlust and attack an Electabuzz. Kyle quickly captures the Volcano Koffing sign in the following run. Reiner rushes through the River level and misses his sign but is allowed the Super Replay's first restart. The rough start mulligan pays off and the Cubone sign is captured. The final Valley level sees an immediate Dugtrio sign capture by Kyle unlocking the final level; Rainbow Cloud. The episode closes with Reiner capturing the Super Replay's highest score: an 8,500 point Mew.

description: Sonic the Hedgehog is the featured game for the 38th installment of Super Replay, continuing the 12/31 tradition of playing terrible games. This is the first 12/31 Super Replay without Tim Turi, so it's a departure from the survival horror games that are typically played on 12/31. This can be seen as a new beginning for the 12/31 Super Replay - moving on from OverBlood and games of its ilk, and expanding the definition of "bad" Super Replay games.
The first episode of the Sonic the Hedgehog Super Replay has Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, and Ben Reeves at the controls, with guest Joe Juba.

in_this_episode: Intro Cutscene: We start off watching the introduction, which introduces our main characters, Princess Elise (not to be confused with Elise Favis), Dr. Eggman, and our hero Sonic the Hedgehog. We also see a mysterious "white Sonic". Reiner tells us that Elise and Sonic will be making out in this game, so stay tuned. This intro cutscene reminds Kyle of Final Fantasy Kingsglaive.

Soleanna: Gameplay starts off in the open-world city of Soleanna. Here, they test out some shoes from Alberto Robert, in a mission called "The winder of a Shoemaker" (??). These shoes allow Sonic to enter the first level, Wave Ocean.

Wave Ocean: Sonic collects a bunch of rings, and rides a whale. Then Tails starts to shut the gate, to block the whale, but it only goes halfway down. The whale, however, gets the idea and backs off. During this level, we learn that Joe Juba never walks down hallways, on principle. What a weird guy.
Soleanna: Back to the city. Here we discover Sonic's alter ego, Sonic the Hedgehole (or Sonic the Asshole), who takes a soccer ball from a group of kids and kicks it into the ocean. What a jerk!

Boss Fight: Egg-Cerberus: Kyle finds himself getting emotionally attached to this giant creature, comparing it to The Last Guardian. However, it must be killed to continue with the story, so Kyle reluctantly "grinds the tail" and eventually slays it.

Dusty Desert: After some hilarious deaths, falling through the sand at high speeds, they discover how to get past it, and finish this mostly uneventful level. At the end, we're treated to a cutscene of Sonic and Elise slowly falling in love. Then Sonic forces her to run at an insane speed, almost tearing her arm off in the process. This episode ends with the dramatic reveal of Silver the Hedgehog, who vows to destroy Sonic for some reason.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay - Sonic The Hedgehog: Episode 1
youtubeVideo.description: Join Andrew Reiner and crew on this adventure into the borderline unplayable Sonic The Hedgehog from 2006. New episodes every Sunday and Tuesday!

description: The second episode of the Sonic the Hedgehog Super Replay has Ben Reeves, Andrew Reiner, and Joe Juba at the controls, with guest Kyle Hilliard.

in_this_episode: Boss Fight: Silver the Hedgehog: This is an absolute disaster. Silver keeps freezing Sonic in midair whenever he gets close, killing Sonic without any chance to fight back. They quickly look up a walkthrough and figure out the strategy. It's still terrible, but they manage to defeat him. Silver says that the Iblis Trigger must be destroyed, whatever that means. Amy is introduced. She holds off Silver, while Sonic goes after Elise.

Soleanna: Sonic decides to fight the Soleanna Boys, a group of little kids. Joe reveals that he has no problem beating up children in real life, as a grown man. What a weird guy. Sonic finds Pele, the Beloved Dog, and has to walk very slowly, which is a whole lot of fun. Sonic the Hedgehole breaks up a tea party with four identically dressed men, by attacking the men then running off. The soldiers in the city then put together a logic puzzle for Sonic to see if he is worthy. Okay guys. Then Sonic needs to find Knuckles for some reason. In the process, he gets a disk for some guy, with classified info on it, by "destroying all enemies in the New City". The crew discusses their plans for the Game Informer floating car, based on Joe's designs from 3rd grade. Joe is now Senior Magnetics Engineer. Sonic kills a bunch of robots, while the crew discusses Sonic the Hedgehole's favorite drink, Bag O' Blue Nuts. This is a hot, lumpy drink that comes in a bag, similar to Ben Reeves' favorite beverage, warmed-up old bowls of Rice Krispies. We find Knuckles, which is when Wade Wojcik chimes in to tell us that echidnas (like Knuckles) have a four-headed penis. He gets this information from penile scientist Dick Cocks. Thanks Wade.
White Acropolis: A terrible snowboarding level. This ends in failure, sending them back to a WAY earlier checkpoint to end the episode.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay - Sonic The Hedgehog: Episode 2
youtubeVideo.description: Join Andrew Reiner and crew on this adventure into the borderline unplayable Sonic The Hedgehog from 2006. New episodes every Sunday and Tuesday!

description: The third episode of the Sonic the Hedgehog Super Replay has Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, Joe Juba, and Ben Reeves at the controls.

in_this_episode: White Acropolis: Continues with the snowboarding from last time. We learn that Reiner farts when pressing buttons really hard. We also learn that Brian Shea is the densest and whitest material on Earth (with snow taking second place in both categories). Joe Juba, GI's resident snowman (because he knows a lot about snow and men), gets in a plug for his Sonic fan art, which reveals the color of Sonic's penis. What a weird guy.

Crisis City: We see a cutscene, in which Reiner admires Eggman's legs, and Sonic and friends are sent to the distant future. There they meet Shadow and Rouge. Then the level starts, with fire everywhere and raining cars. Reiner calls this level the biggest pile of Shea he has ever seen. Here, Ben Reeves reveals a few "Ben-ventions":
Pogrow Sticks - like pogo sticks that are also Chia pets
Ear Pugs - ear plugs that look like pugs
Garden Garb - a shirt you wear that has plants growing on it
After failing this level a few times (the final time, Sonic just kills himself before they even gain control), they decide to switch to Silver's episode for a while.
Crisis City (Silver Episode)

in_this_episode: "That was an S if I ever saw one." Kyle proclaims after a grueling 10 minute fight with Mephiles.

description: Shenmue II is the featured game in the thirty-seventh installment of Super Replay. It premiered on Oct 1, 2016. It was created by Sega AM2 the developers of the thirtieth Super Replay installment, Shenmue.
The first episode of the Shenmue II Super Replay has Kyle Hilliard at the controls, with Andrew Reiner cohosting.

youtubeVideo.description: Join Game Informer's Andrew Reiner and Kyle HIlliard as they pick up Ryo's journey right where they left off with Shenmue II. Originally released on the Dreamcast in 2001, this is the Xbox version of the game, published by Microsoft in 2002.

description: Martian Gothic: Unification is the featured game of the thirty-third installment of Super Replay. It continues the 12/31 tradition of playing terrible games. It is the last 12/31 Super Replay to feature Tim Turi and the last to fit the survival horror theme.

title: Super Replay: Mortal Kombat: Shaolin Monks

description: Mortal Kombat: Shaolin Monks is the featured game of the 23rd installment of Super Replay. It premiered on March 22, 2014 and ended on April 20, 2014. Andrew Reiner and Dan Ryckery host and play cooperatively. This is the only official Super Replay to date played cooperatively, and the only installment with only two hosts.

description: Illbleed was the featured game in the twenty-second installment of Super Replay. It premiered on December 30, 2013 and continues the 12/31 tradition of playing terrible games; despite being released a day early.  It featured Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, and Dan Ryckert. It was created by Crazy Games (formerly known as Climax Graphics) the developers of the fifteenth Super Replay installment Blue Stinger.

description: Cyberia 2 was the featured game in the twenty-first installment of Super Replay. It premiered on November 16, 2013. It was hosted by Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, Dan Ryckert, and Zach Pligge. It is the sequel to the thirteenth Super Replay installment Cyberia, a game made famous for just how much it frustrated Tim Turi.

The sequel improved almost nothing, and in some cases was actually worse than its predecessor. Although Tim still considers the original Cyberia to be the worst game he has ever beaten (which the crew was surprised with, as it looked to them like Cyberia 2 was worse), he was still quite frustrated by this game as well for very similar reasons, asking out loud in the second episode, "How does it suck so bad in so many similar ways to the original? How did they learn nothing!?" Dan Ryckert agreed, stating, "If you didn't have a walkthrough, this game would be unbeatable."

description: Blue Stinger is the featured game of the fifteenth Super Replay. Blue Stinger was first discovered as the Replay Roulette in the Sonic Adventure Replay. It premiered on December 31, 2012 and ended on February 14, 2013. It's the third Super Replay to continue the 12/31 tradition of playing terrible games (after OverBlood and OverBlood 2). The editors decided on this game and its premier date on the spot during Episode 17 of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay.

description: The first episode of the Cyberia Super Replay has Tim Turi at the controls with Andrew Reiner as host, with guests Dan Ryckert and Jeff Cork. This was the original crew to be featured on the Replay Roulette segment where Cyberia was discovered.

in_this_episode: The episode begins with Tim selecting medium difficulty for both arcade and puzzles (something that, in later episodes, the rest of the crew would urge him to reconsider).

Playing as a character named Zak, whose back-story is not given any mention in the game itself (but is detailed quite extensively in the instruction manual for some odd reason), the first part of the game takes place in an oil rig in the ocean, where Zak has to pick up a computer-automated fighter jet (or "trans-fighter") to fly to Siberia, Russia, where the final section of the game takes place, infiltrate a scientific research complex, and find a top-secret project called the Cyberia Weapon. Immediately upon arriving, a PA announcement tells Zak to "take the door on the right, and don't wander around."

Tim wanders around, though, and seven minutes into the game, he discovers the first instance of a recurring problem in Cyberia: just how easy it is to die without any warning. He is shot to death by a character that the crew notices bears a resemblance to Mike Ehrmantraut from Breaking Bad, so they refer to him as Mike henceforth.

Eventually, Tim goes through the correct door and progresses the story, defending the oil rig from an attack by operating a turret. Afterwords, Zak kisses a woman he met three minutes prior, causing the apparently jealous owner of the rig to take him hostage. In a scuffle, both he and the woman are killed, freeing Zak. Tim guides Zak through two shootouts, both of which are against people who look like Mike, and then disarms a bomb on the trans-fighter, which he then boards and flies away on.

It should be noted, however, that all of the above takes up most of the replay episode, largely because Tim dies over a dozen times due to various different causes without any sort of warning. These deaths include, but are not limited to: slipping on spilled oil, sticking Zak's hand in a barrel of burning acid, failing to disarm a bomb due to a laughably absurd-looking puzzle, walking off a suspended platform, and being shot to death by the stealthy and seemingly ever-present Mike.
The episode ends with a preview of what is to come: a series of rail-shooter levels, which Tim quickly comes to detest.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay: Cyberia: Episode 01
youtubeVideo.description:
Join Game Informer's Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, and Dan Ryckert on the first episode of Super Replay: Cyberia.

Watch the full series here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL6CA20EDB748C44D1

description: The second episode of the Cyberia Super Replay has, like the previous episode, the exact same crew: Tim Turi at the controls, Andrew Reiner as host, and with guests Dan Ryckert and Jeff Cork.

in_this_episode: In this episode, the trans-fighter begins its flight path on what was described in the opening scene of the game as the "optimal route" to the Cyberia complex. A rather odd description, considering that the optimal route apparently includes an entire military of bad guys in six separate locations. Inconveniently, the automatic weapons system fails, so while the flight is automated, the shooting isn't.

So, Tim is forced to suffer through six rail-shooting levels, five of which are featured in this episode. On top of not being particularly enjoyable, Tim notes that the D-pad is the only way of moving the firing cursor, making many of the levels incredibly frustrating to play. The most notable is the fourth one, which takes place in a short but narrow traffic tunnel containing both enemy forces and oil trucks that explode if shot even once. Because of how many enemies there are on screen at any given time, as well as the unresponsiveness of the D-pad controls, it takes the crew twenty minutes to beat, resulting in loud applause for Tim when he finally does. The episode concludes with a few short attempts at the fifth level.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay: Cyberia : Episode 02
youtubeVideo.description:
Join Game Informer's Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, and Dan Ryckert on the second episode of Super Replay: Cyberia.

Watch the full series here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL6CA20EDB748C44D1

description: The second episode of the Cyberia Super Replay has, like the previous episode, the exact same crew: Tim Turi at the controls, Andrew Reiner as  host, and with guests Dan Ryckert and Jeff Cork.

in_this_episode: This episode begins where the last one left off, at the fifth rail-shooting level. The trans-fighter stops for refueling, the animation of which is so overly simplistic that the crew finds it hilarious.

The sixth rail-shooting level--the final one before reaching the Cyberia complex--proves to be the most difficult for Tim, taking him a half hour to beat, and he often dies just before the final enemy. At one point, he gets farther than he has ever been before, leading Dan to shout incoherent but excited noises, which in turn causes the normally patient Tim to snap, "Dan, shut the hell up!" Although Tim apologizes soon after, and even Dan concedes that Tim should have yelled at him, by this point, the game has clearly taken a toll on Tim's sanity (to the comedic amusement of everyone around him).

The trans-fighter lands in a snowy mountain range a few yards away from the complex, and Zak disembarks, leading the crew to rejoice that they're back on the ground and don't have to suffer through more rail-shooting levels. Instead, they get into a shootout at the entrance of the complex with Mike--yet again--and suffer more hilariously unprompted deaths while trying to get into the complex (one of which is dying due to overly loud background noise).
The episode concludes with the crew unsure of what to do next, finding that the farthest door into the complex is guarded. By Mike. Again.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay : Cyberia: Episode 03
youtubeVideo.description:
Join Game Informer's Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, and Dan Ryckert on the third Episode of Super Replay: Cyberia.

Watch the full series here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL6CA20EDB748C44D1

description: As with with the previous episodes, the crew remains the same: Andrew Reiner as host, with guests Dan Ryckert and Jeff Cork. Tim Turi is once again at the controls.

in_this_episode: The episode begins with the crew making a few more attempts to get further into the complex, but Tim eventually concedes that he has no idea what he's doing. Finally, they figure out that they confused a door for a wall, and unknowingly unlocked it in the last episode. They progress through it, only to get in a shootout with four Mikes.

After successfully getting through that, they access video messages ("V-mail") from employees who used to work at the complex before being killed, and the crew laughs at how hideously ugly the sub-par graphics make most of them appear. They also experience the oddity of going through a sleeping quarters and watching Zak merely say, "Hmm..." when he sees a pair of boxers.

Further in, they sneak up on two Mikes who are gathering information about the Cyberia Weapon. A shootout ensues with one of the Mikes...again...and they access a password-protected computer to look at more V-mail. Not sure of what to do next, they go back the way they came, only to be hilariously killed when another Mike pops out of an elevator and throws a flash grenade at Zak. The episode ends after a few fruitless attempts to get past this particular Mike.
The highlight of this episode is probably the fact that, a little over forty minutes into this episode, Mike's actual name is revealed to be Arnold, but the crew is talking too loud to hear it.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay: Cyberia: Episode 04
youtubeVideo.description:
Join Game Informer's Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, and Dan Ryckert on the fourth episode of Super Replay: Cyberia.

Watch the full series here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL6CA20EDB748C44D1

description: As with with the previous episodes, the crew remains the same: Andrew Reiner as host, with guests Dan Ryckert and Jeff Cork. Tim Turi is at the controls.

in_this_episode: The episode begins where the last one left off, with the crew trying to get past the Mike who is throwing a flash grenade at them. Tim remarks that Overblood, which the crew previously held up as "the worst game ever" really doesn't deserve that title, because Cyberia has turned out to be far, far worse.

Eventually they discover that a seemingly insignificant series of shapes they found on a V-mail file is in fact a password to lock the elevator that Mike keeps popping out of. They shoot Mike before he can lob the flash grenade at them, and then lock him in. The flash grenade goes off inside the elevator with the doors closed, killing Mike and allowing Zak to move on.

The problem is, the crew has no idea what to move on to, because the game gives them no indication. They stumble around until they discover that Mike is absent from another area of the complex that he previously guarded. They explore that area (after being killed by a separate Mike, who suffocates Zak by turning on a room's halon system without warning). After getting in another shootout with another Mike, they access a computer terminal and open the vents to a room where a dead man is being kept, making it possible for them to obtain a card key to move on to the next are of the complex. Unfortunately, before they can, they find themselves in yet another shootout with two more Mikes. Fortunately, these prove to be the final Mikes they have to deal with in the game.
The episode ends with them using the card key they found to get into another room.
memorable_quotes_from_the_crew: Tim (stunned after a flash grenade, normally used for blinding and deafening an enemy, instead explodes and consumes Zak's body): I am....what?......I'm so happy I'm playing this with people, otherwise I'd have no idea what was real......WHAT!?

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay: Cyberia: Episode 05
youtubeVideo.description:
Join Game Informer's Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, and Dan Ryckert on the fifth episode of Super Replay: Cyberia.

Watch the full series here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL6CA20EDB748C44D1

description: Like the previous episodes, the crew remains the same: Andrew Reiner as host, with guests Dan Ryckert and Jeff Cork. Tim Turi is once again at the controls, despite his increasingly stronger wishes that he wasn't.

in_this_episode: This episode resumes with the crew verbally hoping that this is will be the last episode of the Cyberia Super Replay. It won't be.

Starting in the room that they got access to by using the card key, they access a terminal and watch two V-mails, but they don't listen carefully enough to determine what they're supposed to be doing. Eventually, they look up a guide that says a horrible virus has spread throughout a section of the complex up ahead, and that while three vaccines exist, they've all been contaminated, and need to be at least 72% decontaminated by means of a nano-probe in order to be usable. Upon activating the nano-probe, the crew discovers, to Tim's utter horror, that the decontamination process takes the form of...
...Another rail-shooting level.
After many tries and several deaths from traveling into the contaminated area without a usable vaccine, Tim manages to decontaminate a vaccine, and Zak successfully immunizes himself.

Going further into the complex, the crew laughs hysterically when they open a door and, without any warning, a small creature flies through and begins eating Zak's face, resulting in yet another hilariously unprompted death. They access a nearby computer terminal and learn that flesh-eating creatures called nanites (although the crew calls them "face-huggers") have infested the final area of the complex before the Cyberia Weapon. The only way to solve the problem is to send in a remote probe called Charlie, equipped with an electricity gun, and destroy every single one of the face-huggers.

This process is, once again, a rail-shooter. And this time, it's arguably the most difficult one of all due to the fact that literally every single face-hugger that appears on screen has to be destroyed. There is a shockwave device installed to kill face-huggers that manage to fly off-screen, but it needs to be used within 2-3 seconds of the face-hugger escaping, and it uses up a significant amount of Charlie's energy. As a result, Tim suffers many losses due to Charlie shutting down.
The game ends with Tim realizing the true horror of what he must endure to complete the game.
memorable_quotes_from_the_crew: 1) Tim (upon realizing that the vaccine decontamination sequence is a rail-shooting level): Does a rose by any other name still smell like s***?
2) Tim (after dying from the first face-hugger): Oh God....what IS this GAME!?
3) Tim (after realizing that he really does have to kill every face-hugger): Oh my GOD...
Dan (laughing at Tim's misery): Oh NO...
Tim: Do you know what this MEANS!?
4) Dan: We should get [Cyberia creator] Drew Markham to fly out here for our Cyberia 2 Super Replay.
Tim: That actually would be amazing.
Tim: Force him to play it.
Reiner (to Markham): Look what you did!

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay: Cyberia: Episode 06
youtubeVideo.description:
Join Game Informer's Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, and Dan Ryckert on the sixth episode of Super Replay: Cyberia.

Watch the full series here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL6CA20EDB748C44D1

description: Andrew Reiner hosts, with Tim Turi at the controls, and Dan Ryckert and Jim Reily as guests.

in_this_episode: This episode picks up with Tim making another attempt at completing the rail-shooting level that is the Charlie probe sequence, which he first began in the previous episode. It is this sequence, perhaps more so than any other in the game, that nearly breaks the normally patient Tim Turi's sanity for good. He simply finds himself unable to complete the sequence, despite turning the brightness all the way up, enlisting the help of his guests to memorize where the face-huggers will appear, and ignoring pleas from Reiner and the guests to decrease the difficulty level. Tim goes through a hell that most people wouldn't wish on their worst enemies, drudging through a grueling 38 minutes of failed attempts (even longer if one counts the few attempts made in the last episode).
Finally, Tim's salvation arises in the form of a beautiful suggestion: using a mouse instead.

The crew did not initially think of that because they didn't think they had a mouse that would be compatible with a Playstation, but once they realize that they do, they plug it in (after switching from a PS3 to a PS2 because the mouse wasn't compatible), and Tim finds himself empowered with the lightning-fast movement and sensitivity that the mouse affords him. It still takes him a few tries, but after 10 minutes, he finally completes the Charlie probe sequence.

The crew finally gets to the Cyberia Weapon's chamber after one last incoherent puzzle. Upon seeing what they think is the Weapon--some sort of speaking object that looks like a giant silver walnut with a purple gem--Zak gets a transmitted message from his boss, who reveals that Zak is, in fact, the real Weapon. The crew laughs at how stupid the plot twist is, and proceed to merge Zak with the Weapon as per the game's story, creating one of the most awkward-looking things the crew has ever seen (with Dan remarking that the result looks like a waffle iron). The merged Zak and Cyberia Weapon then fly off into space for the final showdown with Zak's boss.
A rail-shooting level.
The episode ends after Tim attempts the level two times.
memorable_quotes_from_the_crew: Tim (upon seeing Zak merged with the Cyberia Weapon): This is....this is the worst s***....

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay: Cyberia: Episode 07
youtubeVideo.description:
Join Game Informer's Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, and Dan Ryckert on the seventh episode of Super Replay: Cyberia.

Watch the full series here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL6CA20EDB748C44D1

description: The final episode of the Cyberia Super Replay has Tim Turi at the controls, and Andrew Reiner as host, with guests Dan Ryckert and Jim Reily (declared "the savior of the last episode" due to his suggestion that Tim use a mouse).

in_this_episode: In this final episode, the crew watches as Tim guides the merged Zak/Cyberia Weapon (which they have dubbed "the Flying Space Waffle") to a space station where Zak's boss, revealed to be the true antagonist of the game, is residing. One final rail-shooting level ensues, in which the Flying Space Waffle destroys the station. In effect, Tim manages to do something he has wanted to do for some time: beat the game.

...Only to find out that the game glitches right after he made the last shot by still having enemies appear on screen even as the final cut-scene begins. He instinctively shoots back, which freezes the game. Tim then realizes that he has to do the level all over again in order to truly beat the game and see the ending. He does manage to beat it a second time, managing to prevent the glitch by not firing back at the enemies that appear when the final cut-scene begins.

............Only to find out that there was literally about eight seconds left of the cut-scene after the point at which his game froze, consisting merely of a brief shot of the Flying Space Waffle burning up in the atmosphere and then crashing into a horribly-rendered mountain. The final insult is that there's not even an after-credits ending sequence.
The credits roll, with Tim vowing revenge on every name that pops up.
memorable_quotes_from_the_crew: 1) Tim (after seeing how brief and unsatisfying the ending is): There is....there is literally more of an epilogue in Mario 1!
2) Tim (after the glitch happens): God, even when you BEAT the game, it's still Cyberia!
3) Reiner (upon completing the game): We probably...took ten years off of Tim's life.

description: Half-Life is the featured game of the eleventh installment of Super Replay. It was scheduled to premier in the first week of April 2012, but was delayed due to technical issues and a magazine deadline. The first episode eventually aired on May 3, 2012.
Dan Ryckert picked Half-Life as his game for Super Replay Showdown, and is hosting the Super Replay and playing the game.

Episode 1 is the debut episode of the Half-Life Super Replay.  After many delays (much like Valve) the episode aired on May 3, 2012.  This episode features Dan Ryckert (on the mouse and keyboard), Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, and Ben Hanson.  In this episode Dan plays through the first three chapters (Black Mesa Inbound, Anomalous Materials, and Unforseen Consequences) and gets a fair way through Office Complex with the episode ending when Dan receives his first grenade.

description: OverBlood 2 is the featured game of the tenth installment of Super Replay. It premiered on December 31, 2011 and ended on February 23, 2012 with episode 20, making it the longest Super Replay (as of August 2012). It continues the 12/31 tradition of playing terrible games established with it's prequel OverBlood. It is the most anticipated Super Replay to date, due to the popularity of the OverBlood Super Replay.

Prior to the airing of the Super Replay, knowledge began to circulate among the OverBlood fanbase and Game Informer staff of a glitch affecting some copies of OverBlood 2 which caused the game to freeze during a certain cutscene, leaving the player unable to progress and therefore unable to complete the game. Game Informer's copy did not include this glitch; however, the crew "faked" the glitch at the end of Episode 5.

Episode 1: Heat It Up is the debut episode of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay. It aired on December 31, 2011, the one-year anniversary of the first OverBlood Super Replay. This episode features Tim Turi (on controls), Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and guest Matt Helgeson (who was on the Revolution X Replay which featured the OverBlood Roulette as well as the first episode of the OverBlood Super Replay.

Although Ben Hanson is not officially credited as a cast member, he has a microphone for this episode (as well as the rest of this Super Replay) and offers commentary and conversation along with the rest of the crew.

This episode features the introductory cutscene of the game, which features many Engrish phrases overlapping with CG and gameplay. The OverBlood 2 Super Replay is tagged as "i felt a guy" in reference to one of these phrases.

description: Episode 2: Some Kind of Equipment is the second episode of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay, which aired on January 2, 2012. This episode features Tim Turi (on controls), Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and guest Ben Reeves.

Although Ben Hanson is not officially credited as a cast member, he has a microphone for this episode (as well as the rest of this Super Replay) and offers commentary and conversation along with the rest of the crew.
The first half of this episode features the crew wandering around East Edge City looking for the Hook Shot. Once they find it, they use it to enter and explore Billboard Island.

Throughout the episode, Ben Reeves makes frequent reference to the coincidental recurrence of the number 2 in this episode. At the beginning, he notes, "we're playing Overblood 2, it's Episode 2, I'm on mic 2... we're on Earth-2... I'm taking a 2... save file 2..." Later, the crew notes the similarities between OverBlood 2 and Attack of the Clones, which is Star Wars: Episode II.

description: Episode 5: The Supreme Dumb Thing is the fifth episode of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay, which aired on January 9, 2012. The episode features Tim Turi (on controls), Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and guest Phil Kollar.

Although Ben Hanson is not officially credited as a cast member, he has a microphone for this episode (as well as the rest of this Super Replay) and offers commentary and conversation along with the rest of the crew.

Episode 5 is probably most well known for being the episode in which the Replay crew "faked" the game-ending glitch that affected certain copies of OverBlood 2. This caused some controversy among some members of the Replay fanbase, who believed that the Replay crew had "given up" on seeing the rest of OverBlood 2.

Other members of the fanbase, however, correctly guessed that the glitch was a ruse, and after skipping one update day to keep up the facade, the Replay crew aired Episode 6 of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay the subsequent Friday.

description: Episode 6: Don't Stop Me Now is the sixth episode of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay, which aired on January 13, 2012. This episode features Tim Turi (on controls), Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and guest Phil Kollar.

Although Ben Hanson is not officially credited as a cast member, he has a microphone for this episode (as well as the rest of this Super Replay) and offers commentary and conversation along with the rest of the crew.

This is the first episode of the OverBlood Super Replay after the game-ending glitch was "faked" at the end of Episode 5. As a result, the episode begins with a recap of what really happened after the countdown at the end of Episode 5. Episode 6 proper starts at 18:18.
Dan Ryckert notes during the episode that Episode 6 was filmed about a month after Episode 5, following the staff's holiday break.

The gang makes staggeringly little progress during this episode, as the majority of the episode as them watching cut scenes. The episode ends with Andrew signing Queen's "We Are the Champions" over a black screen.

description: Episode 10: Upping the Andy is the 10th episode of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay, which aired on January 23, 2012. This episode features Tim Turi (on controls), Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and Game Informer editor-in-chief Andy McNamara as guest in his first-ever Replay appearance (the episode's title is a pun on this fact which was created by Tim in an upcoming episode).

Dan tries to convince Andy that people watch the Super Replay by giving out code words; a fact that Andy mocks. Dan then forces Andy to come up with a word, and Andy says. The episode ends when Tim fails to hookshot up some floating islands.

description: Episode 13: Welcome to Hell is the 13th episode of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay, which aired on February 1, 2012. The episode gets its title from a neon sign found within the game, which reads "WELCOME TO HELL" in bright Comic Sans-esque font.

This episode features Tim Turi (on controls), Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and Game Informer editor-in-chief Andy McNamara as an unexpected repeat guest. Although Ben Hanson is not officially credited as a cast member, he has a microphone for this episode (as well as the rest of this Super Replay) and offers commentary and conversation along with the rest of the crew.
As Dan notes near the beginning, this episode marks the point at which OverBlood 2 became the longest Super Replay to date, surpassing the Mega Man Legends Super Replay which ran for 12 episodes.
This sign found in the facility gave the episode its title.

episode_summary: The episode begins with each editor begging for release from the Super Replay, and Dan Ryckert accusing Andy McNamara of banana sabatoge. This leads to all editors agreeing that if Dan broke his neck, they would end the Replay. They go on to discuss Andy's hidden love of Replay, using evidence such as him buying a Tail of the Sun shirt, even though he insists the game is a nightmare. They discuss 1991 movies, what would happen if Dan was President, Jake "The Snake" Roberts and unsurprisingly, Resident Evil and Terminator.

Once inside, they puzzle over keycard collection, until Dan insists they burn an allegedly "IMPERVIOUS TO HEAT" box. It works, much to his joy and the rest of the group's annoyance. The Red Key Card reveals a pool, and the episode ends.
plot_summary: Acarno retreads the Deceptive Forest for the third(!) time. This time, he reaches Tornado Island and defeats a six-legged robo-tiger. Acarno enters the facility to rescue an important doctor and sees a massive guillotine with a neon sign reading, "Welcome to HELL". He explores multiple disturbing puzzle rooms such as an over-stimulating excercise room and one full of floating platforms. After uncovering a Red Key Card by burning a fireproof box, Acarno reveals a large pool. As he prepares to dive in, the episode concludes.
credit_cookies: Brief post-episode banter where Andy hopes Dan slips on a banana peel. Dan counters by saying he will put one behind the back tire of Andy's car.
A muffled voice saying they are "just about ready to stop". Then Andrew Reiner impersonating Dan Ryckert.

description: Episode 14: Atlus Shrugs is the 14th episode of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay, which aired on February 2, 2012. This episode features Tim Turi (on controls), Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and Atlus PR manager Aram Jabbari as guest. Aram previously had a guest appearance on the Metal Warriors episode of Replay.

Although Ben Hanson is not officially credited as a cast member, he has a microphone for this episode (as well as the rest of this Super Replay) and offers commentary and conversation along with the rest of the crew.

notes: This episode begins with the Replay crew standing in front of Jemelgalda's hidden pool.
editor_antics: At the beginning of the episode, Aram relates his knowledge of OverBlood 2: "I just heard about Overblood 2 about two hours ago." He also spots a Gold Key Card in the pool that Tim swims in, but neglects to tell the team so as not to rob them of the reward of finding it for themselves.

A running joke throughout the episode is the Replay crew asking Aram if he could convince Atlus to produce OverBlood 3, with Aram responding that Atlus would no doubt be intrigued and that he would use his sway within the company to create a meeting on the topic, since the obvious quality of OverBlood 2 is apparent to him.

The episode features a battle with a flashy dominatrix, to which Aram quips, "Reminds me of someone I dated." Tim begins using the Super Light Sabre, at which point Dan reminisces to Aram about the battle with the Terminator T-Rex. As Tim cycles through his other weapons - the Laser Gun, Grenade Launcher, and Flame Thrower - Aram responds incredulously that such weapons were not the group's first choice.
Afterwards, they enter another boss fight with Head of Security Adidi Blago, a fat businessman with a quarterstaff. Once again utilizing the flame thrower, Adidi is defeated.

A long cutscene comes and goes, and Aram discusses the process of localization with Ben Hanson. They misunderstand Acarno's dialogue with a child thief, making the whole interaction very awkward. They pursue the child after he steals their banana and enter the next Chapter titled "Edgy Kids". They are soon attacked by a mob of gangsters, which the team has serious reservations about killing, but find it required to continue. They find out that when they stand behind the gangsters, they will throw knives into their own chests to try and kill Acarno; this reminds Dan of the time a Revolver Ocelot wannabe in college shot his own penis.

They enter a bar with a bad gas leak and a guy sleeping in his own blood, prompting Tim to say a Deathklok reference. A man hires Tim to be a hitman and kill the local gangs for him to improve store prices. As they fight another group of enemies, Dan remembers State Of Emergency and the infuriating lack of enthusiasm for a 3D GTA amongst his friends. Reiner and Aram enthusiastically remember the game Quarantine. Ben Hanson asks Aram what the licensing for the game would be like nowadays, and Aram decides it is 1000 horsemeat burgars. From then to the end of the episode, they chuckle at on-screen events.
overblood_2_antics: Acarno dries up the pool to find a Gold Key Card to free the doctor. Before he can, he banters with and fights a dominatrix. No match for his widely varied arsenal and skill, she is defeated and the doctor freed. Before they can escape, the Head of Security attacks. Acarno has a genuinely good quip, then defeats him as well. After escorting him back to base, the doctor helps to fix the Hull Drive. Meanwhile, Hasaka reveals that he founded the Children of Earth, a terrorist organization that worships the Earth as a god, as a front to stall Hayano Industries from constructing their ship. After much techno babble, the Drive fails to fire. While the scientists in the group sort it out, Chris comforts Hasaka and Acarno unwinds in the town, but doesn't get far before Hayano's payroll cops try to capture him. He's saved by a child thief who tells him about Marius, a telepathic old woman at his gang's hideout. Acarno attempts to trade a banana for information, but the kid instead tries to run off with the banana, and Arcano chases him into the dangerous part of town. Acarno gets a lead on where the kid may have gone, but must eliminate six gangs surrounding the bar before the ownerwill give him a key to the ghost house where Marius may be. He triumphs over the gangs through superior knowledge of explosives, tricking the gangsters into Hara-Kiri, and the his most trusted weapon, the flame thrower. Acarno collects his reward and sets off for the ghost house.
quotes: Acarno: "More like Head of Insecurity!"
Adidi Blago: "I should have learned how to fire automatic weapons instead of training of Kendo..."
Aram Jabbari: "The game is finished, it would just be a matter of taking a few 'u's out of the script."
Acarno: "So what now?" Tim: "Keep chasing him! It's not complicated!"
"Don't touch me! I'll kill you!" The first line said by a NPC as soon as Tim begins "Edgy Kids"
Dan: "We fought a Terminator T-Rex. It had a mechanical face with a red eye and everything." Aram: "I was under the impression that was the only kind of dinosaur."
Dan: "You killed a woman with a flame thrower, then took her money!" Tim: "It's like Grand Theft Auto." Aram: "I'm not waiting to get back, I'm calling headquarters right now!"
credit_cookies: Aram asking if Tim is paid extra for having to play through OverBlood 2 and discussing the game a little with the GI staff.
A clip of the child thief shaking his head as Navarro's "Awwww"' plays.

description: Episode 15: Get It On is the 15th episode of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay, which ared on February 7, 2012. This episode features Tim Turi (on controls), Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and guest Matt Helgeson.

Although Ben Hanson is not officially credited as a cast member, he has a microphone for this episode (as well as the rest of this Super Replay) and offers commentary and conversation along with the rest of the crew.

editor_antics: This episode starts with Acarno practicing parkour in a seedy bar. The trio recaps previous events to Helgeson in the most misleading way possible as they search for the Ghost House. They talk about Letterman's "Please Stop Calling Me Chief", a Muay Thai boxer who would not stop saying "bro", Mortal Kombat: Annihilation, and optional groupons. Dan talks about Muay Thai and Matt discusses Capoeira. Using Ben Hanson's advice, they blast their way into the ghost house. After fiddling around a bit, they drop a chandelier from the ceiling and peruse a very inappropriate painting. As they proceed, they discuss Naughty Dog making OverBlood 3 by simply changing the characters in Last Of Us to Raz Karcy and Pipo. Matt Helgeson attempts to equate staff members with Frasier characters. Dan is an easy shoe-in for bull-dog, Andy McNamara is the father, Jeff Marchiafava is Daphne, and Phil Kollar is Niles. They segue into discussing movies of 2011, notably Rise Of The Planet Of The Apes, Super 8, and Money Ball. The team finally get through the mansion and right into a Junk Blade race, which Tim quickly loses. Three times. Then three more times. As he grows more frustrated, Tim barks at everyone to shut up as he scrapes for enough concentration and reflexes to win on the default difficulty. Almost awkwardly, and certainly unprecedented, the Replay room falls completely silent except for Tim's exasperated sighs (this may or may not be due to Hanson editing Dan out of the commentary momentarily). Tim's skill eventually overcomes the steep difficulty and he celebrates gloriously. During a cutscene showing the meeting with Marius, one of the team whistles a Star Wars melody. As it drags on, Tim decides that this is the worst video game story ever. They make the spur of the moment tie-in that Marius is old Mille from OverBlood 1. They beat the chapter "Edgy Kids" with a rank of A, and proceed directly into another cutscene. And another. And another. The team mostly checks out at this point, and discusses how the illustrious producer improved so much. They futilely hope that this is the last episode.
overblood_2_antics: Acarno gains entrance to the ghost house and takes his leave of it in short order. He encounters the leader of the gang behind the house, who claims that Buster, the child thief from the previous episode, said Acarno stole the bananas from him. Acarno attempts to set the record straight but to no avail, and it very nearly comes to blows until he says, "I only came here to look for Doctor Marius!" The leader and his underage thugs are taken aback, as they believe that only they know that Marius used to be a doctor. They wonder if he's "The Traveler", but quickly discards this notion as "The Traveler" is supposed to be kind and gentle, "not stealing bananas from little kids!". Since The Traveler is supposed to be a great Junk Blader, they challenge Acarno to a Junk Blade race, which he readily accepts. He triumphs with ease. He meets Doctor Marius, an old woman who can communicate only telepathically, but very nearly is thrown out before she can speak to him. She contacts him, though, and declares him The Traveler because his power is unmistakable. She explains that Traveler's have powers akin to hers or Acarno's sister. She talks about how they must help the world realize freedom, and tells of her past and the past of the Hull Drive. She talks of how the Hull Drive was meant to help humankind, but it was sabotaged to hurt them. She was captured and tortured, so she shut down her whole body, and is now unable restart it. The gang leader (Craka?) cries that she must leave, but Marius comforts him. There's a short monologue from Chris, and the chapter "Edgy Kids" concludes. The next episode begins with Marius being introduced to the rest of Acarno's friends as a Traveler, and reveals himself to be one as well. Hasaka tells of how Traveler's were exploited for their blood to use in super soldier projects. Hasaka talks about how Travelers are to be utilized as advance scouts on inhospitable planets. With this tactic, Hayano can safely colonize dangerous planets when they abandon Earth. Acarno agrees to act as Marius's proxy body, and the cutscene switches to Xeno on the bridge of the Shangri-La preparing to fire it up. Hayano and Kondo interrupt, to Xeno's dismay. Hayano explains how he suspected of the plan to steal the ship from him since the beginning. He orders Kondo to kill Xeno, but he mutates and knocks them aside. The cutscene goes back to Acarno, who makes final preparations to complete the Hull Drive. The cutscene switches back to Xeno who is still attempting to launch the ship, and then switches back to Acarno as he enables the Hull Drive to work. Acarno listens to Marius' monologue about the Earth regulating itself despite the persistent pollution mankind produces. She hypothesizes that Travelers are Earth's creations to survive on the new, polluted Earth. She urges him to use his powers for good. As their conversation ends, a massive energy drain is reported from area D5. The Shangri-La is close to launching, and when it does everyone will be doomed. A massive sinkhole opens above the Shangri-La, destroying much of the city above.
quotes: Dan "I love Muay Thai, but I'm still bruised up from Tim kicking me a bunch." Tim "That was really great."
"Hanson, get the blur up there, get the blur up there!"
Dan "****? He doesn't have to bleep that I don't think." Ben Hanson "Aaaaah! We went over this a hundred times in BMX XXX!"
"We talked about how you break the 4th wall every episode." Dan "Of Replay? By admitting we have a video producer? He's right there! You can hear him!"
"You ain't nevah gonna ween!" Said by both the kids Tim must race when he loses, and Matt due to the humorous tone the kid says it in.
Ben Hanson "Dan! I hate you so goddamn much! Five! Minutes!"
credit_cookies: The team groans about how long the episode was.
Replays of Xeno's "Haaa!", also "You had no ho-", "You ain't nevah gonna ween!", "You wastin' you time!"

description: Episode 16: Kiss Stalin Goodbye is the 16th episode of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay, which aired on February 9, 2012. This episode features Tim Turi (on controls), Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and guest Phil Kollar.

Although Ben Hanson is not officially credited as a cast member, he has a microphone for this episode (as well as the rest of this Super Replay) and offers commentary and conversation along with the rest of the crew.

episode_notes: The episode begins with the Shangri-La looming in the distance as Acarno practices his spin kicks. Phil is shocked that the Super Replay is still going. The others concur wearily. They hit up the shops one last time for boner lightsaber juice.

Dan discusses his hatred of all Kevin Smith movies, and the rest talk about how he and his Dad constantly scream at each other. Tim breaks into a dramatic tone and narrates their interaction. Andrew Reiner is shocked that Scientologists have a space dragon, and Ben is revealed to have an anti-Scientologist blog. Phil remains hopelessly lost from the plot, so the team resolves to talk about future Super Replays, possibly Psychonauts or Paper Mario. They talk about moon rocks as fuel, and Dan buying stocks in Greece's national bank.

The crew uncovers an exhaustive puzzle, and reluctantly begin to collect the 8 Diva Pieces needed to finally finish the game. Tim tries to destroy the laser crystals, but finds the difficulty significantly increased. As Tim gives up and returns to the beginning of the episode to re-arm, Hanson and Dan discuss replacing Dan with sound bites, "This is like Uncharted", "That's so stupid." "Look at that." They discuss economizing action figures as kids as the episode restarts, then discuss TMNT in general. Dan outs himself as a rich kid in secret, and once again demonstrates miniscule memory retention. They ridicule Acarno's approaches to doors.
overblood_2_antics: Acarno buys a Big Magnum and starts the final mission. Kondo and Hayano argue about Xeno. Kondo wants to let him live long enough to destroy their mutual enemies, like missile bases. Hayano says that Xeno wants to destroy the planet, without colonizing another one. Back to Acarno's group, Hasaka explains that the ship will destroy all the defenses before it hits the Starwatch perimeter, then destroy the planet. He deftly pilots the ship into a trench, and episode 7 "Another Future" begins.

Haska and Acarno exit the ship and make a simple plan: Get to the bridge and stop the lift-off. Meanwhile, the Hayano scientists struggle to stop Xeno's lift-off. In the hanger, Acarno and Co. come under fire. Acarno gets split off by a blast door, and continues on alone. The Ministry of Defense prepares to fire, ignoring the fact they need the President's orders first. However, a power failure prevents them from doing so. Acarno makes it to a stasis room that contains some very strange creatures. Each creature tells him a different clue through their own riddles, explaining he needs 8 Diva pieces to breach the bridge and vaguely where to find them. Acarno also needs to disable 3 holographic shutters, numerous security crystals, and enter the code correctly on the control panel.

Ben Hanson "Lower your voice--"
Tim "Geez! We're losing-- we're losing you on the mic!"

description: Episode 17: The Face of God is the 17th episode of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay, which aired on February 14, 2012. This episode features Tim Turi (on controls), Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and Ben Hanson as an "official" guest (although Hanson appears on every episode of this Super Replay, he is usually not officially credited as a cast member).

notes: The episode's title comes from a text Ben Hanson sent to Dan Ryckert, which Dan directly quotes on the episode to illustrate Ben's penchant for exaggeration: "If you're in the mood to see the face of God, you should download the free iOS game called Triple Town (47:50)."
staff_antics: The episode begins with the team stuck still in the Shangri-La, with progress yet to be made.

Tim is able to pass through the Laser Crystal room with the help of a tip from a viewer, who unfortunately he cannot recall the name of. For this reason, he was reluctant to admit the tip was given to him. Hanson jokes that his name is Deep Throat. As Tim is killed again and again, Dan says Tim's new found "spirit quest", including his new interest in philosophy, rock climbing, his sacrificing of small animals, and his shark-morphing, are based on his horrific experiences with this game. Tim eventually triumphs, and enters the elevator. A cutscene begins, during which the team discusses that TIE fighters should have tigers or pretty ladies painted on them. Dan reiterates his disgust at female armpit hair, as he replayed Metal Gear Solid 2 the day prior. The team also discusses unwinnable boss battles, and the fact that Hanson has played more Virtua Boy than Super Nintendo. The team relaxes considerably after a boss fight with Kondo, laughing their way through a difficult platforming section.

For the last half of the episode, Reiner, Dan, and Ben Hanson all talk of the future of Super Replay. They do not wish to do another "OverBlood" style of game immediately after, and instead want to play a good and short game. Ben Hanson also mentions "Project Mako", named because of sharks, that will occur in March. They then change it to "Project Marcho". Blue Stinger, a very cheesy game like OverBlood, is said to have been pushed to December 31st, the original air date for OverBlood and OverBlood 2. Dan shares his thought on Tim Schafer. Tim then stumbles into a room that is very familiar, the same room that is where Raz Karcy, the protagonist of OverBlood, awakened from Cryogenic sleep. The team freaks right the hell out about it, and the episode ends right there.
overblood_2_antics: Acarno makes short work of the laser crystals. Hayano order Kondo to cut power to the shields, and Kondo does this by punching lightning so hard it explodes. Xeno is taken off guard by this, but activates the Guardian system to preserve the ship. However, he focuses the Guardian around his position, leaving other parts of the Shangri-La vulnerable. Hayano is grievously injured by a pair of missiles that slip through the shield, and calls for help to no avail. Xeno celebrates his victory, and Hayano is crushed under rubble as he dies alone with his dreams burning around him. Hasaka blows through the blast door that separated Acarno from the rest of the party and sets off to find him. Acarno briefly explores the ship, using the elevator to go the Diva Level and encounters Kondo again. Acarno tells him of their Hull Drive and how it can save the Earth, but Kondo says he no longer cares since Hayano is dead and all his hopes are gone with him. An epic sword fight ensues which Acarno wins. After fighting his transformed shape, he returns to normal. An explosion goes off and a column nearly falls on Acarno. Kondo risks his life to save Acarno's, and thanks him for his help and encouraging words. The column proves too heavy and Kondo is crushed by it. Ironically, one of the Diva Pieces is accessible by jumping onto the column that crushed him. In the process of all of this, the antagonist (the replay crew believes) was also crushed. This leads everyone to believe that the end is near. Acarno returns to the lower level, finding it very damaged by the missile fire. He recovers a Diva Piece and returns to the labyrinth, which he navigates to a garden with another Diva Piece. He continues through the labyrinth to a room unfamiliar to Acarno but very familiar to fans of OverBlood 1.
credit_cookies: Dan saying, "King Kong for 360 is the greatest game I ever played."
quotes: Dan "Alucard looks kinda chicky."
Ben Hanson "You should put us kissing the wiki's ass into the wiki as a full quote."
Tim "Channel the dead grandma in you!"
Dan "That jealous doctor. With decades of doctor money!"
Reiner "You're on fire! Burning, burning, burniiiiiing!" Tim: "*Censor Bleeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeep*"

Dan "Yes or no, did you or did you not say, 'King Kong for 360 is the greatest game ever made'?" Ben Hanson "Dan, did you or did you not just say 'King Kong for 360 is the greatest game ever played'?"
Dan: "The Face of God . . ."

description: Episode 18: Some Kind of Butt Thruster is the 18th episode of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay, which aired on February 16th, 2012. This episode features Tim Turi (on controls), Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and guest Ben Reeves.

Although Ben Hanson is not officially credited as a cast member, he has a microphone for this episode (as well as the rest of this Super Replay) and offers commentary and conversation along with the rest of the crew.

staff_antics: Ben Reeves immediately identifies the famous OverBlood 1 room as the room where Ripley was frozen. The team continues with no comment and agrees to return to the clue room to find the last 2 Diva pieces. Ben Hanson is revealed to laugh at everything Ben Reeves says, and when Ben Reeves sees one of the clue monsters, he declares it a "butt thruster", giving the episode a title less than 10 minutes in. The team discusses owls at length while puzzling through the final locations of the Diva pieces. The team then acknowledges their own incompetence, often called out by fans for it, and seek to make a rough schematic of the main floor. Ben Reeves makes a mention of...something, but Hanson bleeps out the entire thing and hollers at him to stop. Judging from the reactions of the hosts, it was something highly offensive and/or something they should not be discussing. The episode ends with the crew desperately trying to find the final piece, which proved futile.
quotes: Tim "What's going on? Did you introduce everyone?" Dan "I think so . . ."
Dan "Owls, one of the few animals with eyes."
Tim "Okay, we can all just stop having fun as soon as I get in on it."

Dan "Ben Hanson, when he said, 'Bad to the bone', what's the first thing that came to my mind?" Ben Hanson "I'm going to go way out on a limb and say, 'Terminator 2'. Though, to be fair, when Ben said 'Owl Towels' the first thing that came to your mind was Terminator 2."
Tim "We already checked the Ocarina of Time room..." Ben Hanson "Wait, think about this for a minute. Alligators don't have shoes." (long pause) "Or purses."
credit_cookies: Ben saying he knows an owl.

description: Episode 19: Xeno-Meridian is the 19th episode of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay, which aired on February 21, 2012. This episode features Tim Turi (on controls), Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and Ben Hanson as an "official" guest (although Hanson appears on every episode of this Super Replay, he is usually not officially credited as a cast member).

staff_antics: The episode begins with the crew finding the final Diva Piece almost immediately by setting a bomb behind a waterfall. The team discusses Hanson's supposed hatred of the Xbox 360 and he is forced to defend himself. They debate over the actual name of Diva, the ship AI, and try in vain to get Acarno to engage preemptive action against Xeno. After groaning at moronic cutscene decisions, Hanson talks of how a friend of his went ice fishing and a dog surprisingly climbed up out of the hole he had cut. They once again try, with no avail, to figure out the plot. Tim begins to suffer from some sort of demonic possession and hallucinations, then discusses the reboot of the Ninja Turtles movies. When the fight against Xeno finally begins, the team laughs at the Dragonball Z-esque antics on the screen. They jinx each other over the words, "Solid Snake Simulation", and once again beg the incompetent heroes to shoot Xeno. As the cutscene goes on, Tim starts to sing Take On Me while the rest debate about an on-screen character's resemblance to Hilary Clinton. All of this makes it quite difficult to fill out the plot details below. They run into a force field in the engine room and try to puzzle through it, when it turns out that they just need to shoot it with the laser gun. Then mecha-Godzilla appears as a boss fight. After beating it and talking about Snow Dogs, they continue into the engine room and end the episode.
overblood_2_antics: Acarno inputs all the Diva Pieces just as Hasaka and Chris catch up to him. Acarno briefly wonders why the bridge wasn't defended, but pushes it aside to stop the ship before the second volley hits. The trio enter the main computer room and confront Xeno. They try to tell him of their Hull Drive, but Xeno won't listen as he is set on establishing his own nation with the ship. Chris draws a gun, and he dares her to shoot, which certainly was not the best idea. She shoots him. He still manages to launch three missiles at Los Angelos, then morphs into an evolved form. Xeno then reveals himself as a Traveler. The missiles detonate and destroy Los Angelos. Xeno launches more missiles and gives Acarno an ultimatum; Acarno must give all his power to Xeno in exchange for cancelling the attacks and saving millions, or resist and let them die. Then Xeno says, "That's what Nina did." Acarno grows furious as he hears how Xeno tricked his sister into giving him more power, then grows sad when he learns she soon gave it up through her own free will. Before she died, she resisted him one last time. Acarno agrees to his offer to save millions in exchange for his power, though Chris and Hasaka urge against it.

Xeno takes him to the lab and tells him humans are outdated and that he has created new artificial humans named Overbloods. Xeno says he was born in a laboratory, and Acarno grows furious that his sister died to create the Overbloods and Xeno. Xeno says her death was a small price to pay, which pushes Acarno over the edge. They fight, with Acarno unleashing the power of the Harbinger. In a genuinely badass fight, Acarno prevails. The heroes then stare at Xeno as he launches the missiles to kill millions of people. He says that the previous attacks were simulations, but these are real. Hasaka decides to take the ship as high as it can go and then self-destruct, while Xeno limps behind and taunts some more. Hasaka reveals himself as the real Hayano, and orders the ascent of the Shangri-La. He reveals that his father grew disgraced with him over reasons unheard and cloned him. Xeno tells them that it makes no difference because the self destruction was preemptively disabled. However, Hayano-Hasaka does not plan to self-destruct, he plans to have Navarro destroy the anti-matter core. Navarro faces a giant Wookiee with armor plating to destroy the engine, and is unsuccessful. Acarno and Co. leave Xeno behind, who is too weak to do any damage, and go to assist Navarro. They quickly develop a plan to crush the large monster under a large blast door. Once they succeed, Acarno enters the engine room.
quotes:: Reiner "You mean the cleavage lady?" Dan "No, the Alucard lady." Reiner "Yeah, the one with all the cleavage."

Ben Hanson "He's an old man, just tackle him!" Dan "Push him off the side!" Reiner "Smash his old face into the keyboard!" Ben Hanson "Use the lighstaber in your pocket!" Dan "Use the laser gun or bazooka!" Tim "Do anything except let him do his thing!"
Tim "We'll let you put in three more cities to destroy, but that's it man! Cool it!"
Tim "Let's see if he's allergic to lightsabers."
